title: The Electric Capacitated Covering Tour Problem
display_name: The Electric Capacitated Covering Tour Problem
primary_location.source.display_name: Anais do Simpósio Brasileiro de Pesquisa Operacional
best_oa_location.source.display_name: Anais do Simpósio Brasileiro de Pesquisa Operacional
abstract: This paper proposes a new problem based on the classic Vehicle Routing Problem (VRP).The problem is called Electric Capacitated Covering Tour Problem (ECCTP) and model a situation where customers can be serviced remotely by covering and only electric vehicles are employed.The ECCTP integrates two research areas: the covering problems and the green logistics.The problem is modeled by Mixed Integer Linear Program (MILP) and solved by a constructive heuristic.A set of benchmark instances is proposed and computational experiments were conducted.

title: STOCHASTIC SIMULATION OF AN OIL TERMINAL TO REDUCE THE TURNAROUND TIME OF TANKERS THROUGH PIPELINE OPERABILITY IMPROVEMENTS
display_name: STOCHASTIC SIMULATION OF AN OIL TERMINAL TO REDUCE THE TURNAROUND TIME OF TANKERS THROUGH PIPELINE OPERABILITY IMPROVEMENTS
primary_location.source.display_name: Anais do Simpósio Brasileiro de Pesquisa Operacional
best_oa_location.source.display_name: Anais do Simpósio Brasileiro de Pesquisa Operacional
abstract: The amount of time oil tankers spend at offshore oil terminals is significant in the oil and gas industry.As a consequence, associated costs are normally relevant.Hence, interventions in such storage facilities to improve its operability are certainly welcome.Therefore, this paper aims to uncover promising initiatives to reduce the turnaround time of tankers at one of Petrobras' terminals.For that, a discrete event simulation approach was used whereby new possible system configurations were investigated.Several scenarios were carried out, from general scheduling solutions to the new equipment installations.Unexpectedly, a useful synergy was noticed: the lower the turnaround time of ships, the lower its variability.With that, an important operational gain is foreseen.Finally, the installation of a cooler equipment improves a pipeline transfer, supporting decreases in both the turnaround time of ships and its associated costs by about thirty per cent.

abstract: In this work, we describe a computational study conducted on The Firefighter Problem (FFP), which models fire spreading and containment in a graph.Once a fire breaks out on a set of vertices, the goal is to save as many vertices as possible with limited resources.Practical applications of the FFP occur in areas such as disease control and network security.The FFP is NP-hard and heuristics have already been proposed.Our main contributions include improvements to an existing Integer Linear Programming formulation that led to an average speedup of 2 to compute exact solutions.Moreover, we developed a novel matheuristic, a technique based on the interoperation between metaheuristics and mathematical programming.We performed extensive experiments on public benchmarks both for parameter tuning and for comparison of our results with those from the literature.A rigorous statistical analysis shows that our new matheuristic outperforms the existing approaches.

title: A mathematical model and a metaheuristic for a job and maintenance machine scheduling problem with sequence dependent deterioration

best_oa_location.source.display_name: Anais do Simpósio Brasileiro de Pesquisa Operacional
abstract: Machines that have a high occupation level commonly present deterioration issues that can severely impact on their performance.In such cases, maintenance activities can be scheduled to restore full productivity.In this work, we deal with the problem of scheduling jobs and maintenance activities on a set of unrelated parallel machines, by considering that the processing time of each job increases according to a deterioration factor that depends both on the machine and on the job itself.The aim is to define the set of schedules that minimize the makespan.We present a linear version of a mathematical model available in the literature, as well as an iterated local search metaheuristic.Extensive computational tests are used to asses the efficiency of the methods and compare them with the recent literature.

abstract: In this work, we study the k-Labeled Spanning Forest Problem.Given a graph with a label assigned to each edge, the goal is to find a spanning subgraph that is a forest with the smallest amount of components and whose edges have at most k different labels.The problem is NP-Hard, and most of the methods proposed in the literature are based on metaheuristics.We study the characteristics of the problem to propose two mathematical models in 0-1 integer and mixedinteger programming.We propose Branch & Cut algorithms to solve the problem by exploring valid inequalities as cuts, branching rules, pruning, bounds, and Benders decomposition.Moreover, we improve the only exact method available in the literature by using paralelism.We carry out computational tests on pseudorandomly generated graphs, showing the best found configurations for the models and Cplex.

abstract: The problem of transporting patients between the area buildings of a hospital is solved in this work.The hospital is composed of different pavilions, each containing a given number of floors.The problem consists of moving the patients between the floors of separate buildings, aiming at minimizing the total weighted lateness.Information about patients arrives on the fly during the day, so that the problem is solved in its dynamic version.Then, a general heuristic is proposed with versions that differ in the way vehicles are positioned after servicing a request.These heuristic versions are compared with each other and with the static version of the problem on instances derived from a real case.In the static problem, all information about the problem is known initially, and then an adaptive large neighborhood search is applied to solve it.

display_name: Multi-depot multiple TSP with pickup and delivery: an VNS approach

abstract: We present a natural variation of the multi-depot multiple Travelling Salesman Problem (MmTSP) which considers pickup and delivery.Hence the notation of our problem: MmTSPPD.This problem must meet requests for transportation between customers and suppliers satisfying precedence.The objective is to find a solution with a minimum total travelling distance.A mixed integer programming model is presented for the MmTSPPD.To solve the MmTSPPD we propose a variable neighborhood search (VNS) that uses the variable neighborhood descent (VND) as local search procedure.We evaluate the performance of this heuristic on a data set adapted from TSPLIB instances.The results show that the VNS proposed is efficient and effective to solve MmTSPPD.

abstract: In this article, the Drone-Assisted Traveling Salesman Problem (DATSP), a new context in which drones are used to extend a classic TSP, is explored.Drones travel unimpeded by traffic and can reach areas of difficult access, whereas other vehicles might not be able to do so.In this new paradigm, an obstacle, such as a river or a mountain, would hinder a company's delivery time to the other side of that obstacle.The drone would then fly repeatedly across it, carrying packages which are then delivered to the clients by a deliveryman.This research is motivated by a real life application, where an Icelandic company started using drones to deliver food across a bay.This operational problem inspired the DATSP, which is modeled mathematically as a Mixed Integer Linear Programming (MILP) problem in this article.Finally, instances were generated and solved with the solver GUROBI and their solutions were investigated.

abstract: This paper proposes a methodology to carry out the integrated planning of MV/LV electricity distribution systems, with renewable energy sources from independent producers, considering environmental aspects related to the emission of greenhouse gases.In the objective function, it is sought to minimize the costs associated with investments, operation, reliability and emission of greenhouse gases, from non-renewable energy sources.For the solution of the generic optimization model established for the problem, we propose a general variable neighborhood search algorithm, composed by neighborhood structures based in intensification and diversification criteria.The algorithm is implemented in C ++ programming language and tests are performed for an integrated 172 bus MV/LV system, with the objective to present the efficiency and robustness of proposed methodology.

abstract: This paper deals the Generalized Traveling Salesman Problem, a variant of the classic Traveling Salesman Problem, where the cities are grouped in clusters, and it is necessary to visit only one city of each cluster.Given its difficulty in solving it optimally in the general case, a hybrid algorithm is developed on this study, combining the metaheuristics Multi-Start and Iterated Local Search (ILS).The ILS is supported by two local searches and one perturbation method, which increases its perturbation ratio after a fixed number of iterations, without improvements on the current solution.Results show the algorithm is competitive when compared with the best algorithms in the literature.

abstract: Concentrated in the northern region of Brazil, the country's 250 isolated systems represent around 1% of the national energy consumption and have been historically supplied by Diesel power plants, an expensive solution that relies on complicated logistics of fuel delivering and responsible for high greenhouse gases emissions in Amazon forest, where most of those systems are located.Although many publications and examples indicate that renewables are already a cost-effective solution, especially for economies dependent on expensive fossil fuels, the conventional generation is still the main source of electricity on isolated systems, even in recent projects.This paper presents an overview of policies and studies done in way of stimulating the use of alternative and environmentally friendly energy sources at off-grid places in Brazil and discuss the probable reasons why this transition has not been driven yet, including barriers related to subsidies, energy tariff and taxes rules.

title: A hybrid heuristic for the overlapping cluster editing problem
display_name: A hybrid heuristic for the overlapping cluster editing problem
primary_location.source.display_name: Anais do Simpósio Brasileiro de Pesquisa Operacional
best_oa_location.source.display_name: Anais do Simpósio Brasileiro de Pesquisa Operacional
abstract: Clustering problems are common in several fields of science.In the graph theory context, a clustering can be made by transforming a graph into a disjoint union of complete subgraphs (clusters) by performing changes to the edge set.This problem is known as the cluster editing problem.However, there are situations when clusters may overlap, i.e., they can share vertices.There are few practical studies regarding the overlapping cluster editing problem in the literature.Then in this paper we propose a hybrid heuristic for the overlapping cluster editing problem.Our hybrid heuristic is based on coupling two metaheuristics, to generate solutions for the cluster editing problem, and a mixed-integer linear program, also introduced in this work, that is solved by using the cluster editing solutions as input.Experimental results show that the proposed hybrid heuristic is able to find good-quality solutions.

abstract: This work considers the well-known Reverse Cuthill-McKee method for sparse matrix/graph bandwidth reduction.This method needs a starting vertex.There are many algorithms for generating it, and one of the best-known is the George-Liu algorithm.This paper reports a computational experiment that compares eight pseudoperipheral vertex finders along with a modified method that is a hybrid of the George-Liu and Kaveh's B algorithms.Our simulations then use the resulting vertices as starting points for the Reverse Cuthill-McKee method for bandwidth reduction of sparse matrices.This paper empirically evaluates nine algorithms over a collection of 50 small symmetric matrix instances.This paper shows numerical evidence for the better performance of this variant compared with eight other algorithms for finding a starting vertex for the Reverse Cuthill-McKee method for bandwidth optimization of small matrices with symmetric sparsity patterns at a higher cost than the George-Liu algorithm.

abstract: Golumbic, Lipshteyn and Stern defined in 2009 the EPG graphs, an intersection graph class based on edge intersection of paths on a grid.An EPG graph G is a graph that admits a representation scheme where its vertices are represented by paths in a grid Q, such that two vertices of G are adjacent if and only if their corresponding paths in Q have a common edge.If the paths in Q have at most k changes of direction (bends), we say that this is a B k -EPG representation.A collection C of sets satisfies the Helly property when every sub-collection of C that is pairwise intersecting has at least a common element.In this paper we show that the problem of recognizing B 1 -EPG graphs that satisfy the Helly property is NP-hard.

abstract: In this work, we study the packing circles problem, in which the items have to be organized within an object.In order to solve these problems, we use the Algencan software, which is based on the Augmented Lagrangian Method.We compare the performance of Algencan's standard version with two strategies that use Newton's method to refine the solutions.One of them is Genpack, which uses Algencan to identify the equations that describe the tangent circles and then it uses Newton's method to solve the resulting system defined by these equations.The other strategy https://proceedings.science/p/106937?lang=pt-br consists of the well known acceleration of Algencan, based on Newton's method for solving the system associated with the KKT conditions, when a reasonable approximation of the solution is found.The numerical tests reveal that the approaches are competitive, with advantage to a modification of Genpack regarding a new criterion for calling the Newton's method.

abstract: This work deals with the mammography unit location problem.In this problem there is a set of mammography units to be installed in cities with hospital infrastructure and a set of cities, each with a demand of mammography screenings.The goal is to decide where to install mammography units in order to maximize the total demand, satisfying the constraints that a woman can not travel more than 60 km to be attended and that not all cities are candidates to host a mammography unit.One mathematical programming formulation and its partial relaxation are presented.The formulations were tested using data from the State of Rondônia, Brazil.Several scenarios were also analyzed, considering the possibility of acquiring more mammography units than those currently available.

abstract: An offshore production system is constituted by several structures, who operate for a defined time.The processes for disposal of these structures after this time is known as decommissioning.For decommissioning of subsea flexible pipes, part of this system, it is recommended to retrieve them, having restrictions from environmental orders as well as related to their arrangement.Such restrictions set challenges for the executive project to the removal of flexible pipes on defining what and in what order vessel's operations should be executed, in a way to minimize the costs to the field operator.In this work, a model based on graph theory is proposed to this flexible pipes' decommissioning problem.

abstract: Coffee is a delicacy that for centuries delight the human palate, Brazil being the main producer and exporter of this delicacy in the world.The commercialization of grains affects the country's economy, generating jobs and increasing national gross domestic product.Thus, this work sought to analyze the performance of forecasting tools to estimate the price of this item.The methodology was based on a comparison between the linear methods and artificial neural networks: Exponential Smoothing, Auto Regressive model (AR) and Auto Regressive Integrated Moving Average model (ARIMA), multilayer perceptron (MLP) and extreme learning machines (ELM).The data were collected from the Center for Advanced Studies in Applied Economics in Brazil (CEPEA) on two types of coffee.After the normalization of the data, the delays were identified and the predictions were made.The computational results showed that the neural networks are capable of reach higher performances than the other models.

abstract: This paper has the objective of investigating the Switch Allocation Problems (SAP), which encompass a series of decision-making faced by power distribution utilities with respect to the number, type and location of sectionalizing switches in a network in order to reduce operational costs while maintaining acceptable levels of reliability.This work addresses a SAP with distributed generation (DG) in the system.DG refers to having an electricity generator at or near the end-user, which can bring loss reduction in the electric network and also help to reduce the impact of system failure.The rationale is that DG may have a positive impact on reliability given its potential to provide alternative power supply paths after a contingency through islanding operation.This research proposes an optimization methodology based on genetic algorithms with a hierarchically structured population to solve the SAP with DG.Computational experiments are conducted to evaluate the methodology on real-life networks.The results show the effectiveness of the approach and the benefits in reliability that can be obtained from the use of DG.

abstract: The complete bipartite graph K 1,3 is a tree know as claw.A graph is said to be clawfree if it contains no induced subgraph isomorphic to the complete bipartite graph K 1,3 .Given a graph G, the NP-hard Graph Declawing Problem (GDP) consists of finding a minimum set S ⊆ V (G) such that G -S is claw-free.This work develops a polyhedral study of the GDP polytope, expliciting its full dimensionality, proposing and testing two families of facets: claw inequalities and star inequalities.In total, two Branch-and-Cut algorithms with separation heuristics have been developed to test the computational benefits of each proposed family on random graph instances.Our results show that the model that uses a separation heuristics proposed for star inequalities achieves better results in almost all cases.

title: Recent Advances on The Berth Allocation Problem
display_name: Recent Advances on The Berth Allocation Problem

abstract: The intermodal transportation of goods by vessels has increased over the years.In this context, the Berth Allocation Problem (BAP) arises and becomes fundamental to guarantee the efficiency of the maritime terminals, deciding where and when to allocate the vessel over a planning horizon taking into account constraints of time and space.Because the problem is proved NP-hard, this study proposes an exact method and analyzes metaheuristics for tackling the problem.First, considering the BAP as a parallel-machine scheduling problem, an approach for this problem is proposed based on an Evolutionary Metaheuristic, aiming to find several good quality solutions in a single round of the algorithm, considering explicitly the BAP with multiple objectives.A lower bound based on a maximal flow problem was derived in order to evaluate the quality of the solutions.Next, based on a heterogeneous vehicle routing problem with time windows a basic Benders Decomposition algorithm and its variants are reviewed and applied to the BAP.Then, a hybrid optimization procedure based on Genetic Algorithm (GA) and Scatter Search (SS)is developed, and data envelopment analysis (DEA) is adopted to choose the efficient combination of the operators for the algorithm proposed.Because most papers in literature use in their experiments data generated randomly, making comparisons between researches difficult, this thesis proposes a problem generator for the BAP, allowing the generation of appropriate test problems to be commonly used with specific desired properties and under controlled conditions.The data are generated using different parameters and the difficulty of solving the BAP with such data is analyzed through the resolution using the CPLEX.Finally, the instances classified as more difficult are solved through two metaheuristics implemented.

abstract: This paper presents a strategy for solving the optimal reactive dispatch (ORD) problem with continuous and discrete control variables; the tap ratios of transformers and shunt susceptances of switchable capacitor banks and reactors are the discrete control variables.The discrete control variables are treated as continuous and handled by either a sinusoidal or a polynomial discretisation function.This elaborate modelling of discrete variables results in a modified ORD and, due to the proposed resolution algorithm, it can be efficiently solved by nonlinear programming methods, such as the Generalised Reduced Gradient algorithm.The efficiency and robustness of the proposed modelling are shown for IEEE benchmark test-systems with up to 300 buses.Test results show the success in providing good solutions while attaining directly the discrete values of controls without further approximations.

abstract: Combinatorial optimization problems, such as the Traveling Salesman Problem and its variations, are main focus of research and discussions.One of its variations is the Traveling Salesman Problem with Draft Limits which has a direct relation with maritime commerce and transportation, by addressing the calculation of router to be followed by a cargo ship without violating draft limit restrictions, aiming to reduce total transports costs.A solution to this problem, when obtained using exact approaches, requires computational effort of an exponential order and, therefore, unfeasible for practical cases.In this sense, heuristic and metaheuristic approaches usually represent alternatives to exact approaches, as it makes it possible to obtain approximate solutions, with less effort.In this article it is proposed a Memetic Algorithm implementation, under the perspective of Evolutionary Algorithms, to solve the problem.At the end of the work, the results obtained are compared with the literature, proving to be competitive with them.

abstract: In this work, we propose valid inequalities to strengthen the linear relaxation of disjunctive models for the job-shop problem minimizing the makespan.These inequalities are obtained based on combinatorial properties of the problem.We show the impact of new inequalities in improving lower bounds of the linear problem relaxation by comparing computational results conducted with the two best existing models for the problem (obtained without and with the addition of these inequalities) in 30 benchmark instances.Based on these computational experiments, we improve linear relaxation bounds in about 87 % of the instances for both models and obtain gaps as good as or better in 50 % of the instances for one of the models and about 67 % for the other.Thus, we expect that the new ideas will open a new theoretical direction for the study of the problem.

abstract: This work presents a model for the problem of cutting two-dimensional irregular items with uncertainty in demand for the items to be cut.The model considers the bin discretized over a grid of points and includes constraints to avoid overlap between items based on the concepts of inner-fit raster and no-fit raster.A two-stage stochastic programming model is proposed to deal with the demand uncertainty, considering a discrete and finite set of scenarios.The objective is to minimize the total cost associated with the strip's production, considering the production of known items (first stage) and the estimated future items (second stage).The preliminary numerical results on generated instances show that the stochastic programming model's solution is advantageous to obtain solutions following the given uncertainties, indicating that randomness impacts and is essential to be considered in the problem.

display_name: Um algoritmo construtivo para o Problema de Roteamento de Unidades Móveis de Mamografia

abstract: This work introduces the Mobile Mammography Units Routing Problem.This problem consists in defining routes for a set of Mobile Mammography Units (MMU) to cover the demand of locations without fixed mammography devices or with an insufficient number of them.The objective is to maximize the demand served and minimize the total distance traveled by the MMUs.We developed a constructive algorithm to generate a solution to the problem.To test it, we used an instance related to a Minas Gerais state region with 444 cities. Considering the current mammography equipment distribution scenario in Minas Gerais, it would be possible to perform 358131 more exams in the State only in the studied area with the presented solution.

abstract: In an exceptionally urbanized world, public transport seems to be more important than ever as it contributes for more sustainable, accessible cities.In an attempt to assist both government agencies and private companies on constructing efficient transport networks, we propose a integer linear programming model to design a demand optimal line with respect to a budget constraint.This text explores particularities of street level transport but the model can be easily generalized for other modes.Preliminary results for grid networks of several sizes and densities were reported.

title: A min-max regret approach for the Steiner Tree Problem with Interval Costs
display_name: A min-max regret approach for the Steiner Tree Problem with Interval Costs
primary_location.source.display_name: Anais do Simpósio Brasileiro de Pesquisa Operacional
best_oa_location.source.display_name: Anais do Simpósio Brasileiro de Pesquisa Operacional
abstract: Let G = (V, E) be a connected graph, where V and E represent, respectively, the nodeset and the edge-set.Besides, let Q ⊆ V be a set of terminal nodes, and r ∈ Q be the root node of the graph.Given a weight c ij ∈ N associated to each edge (i, j) ∈ E, the Steiner Tree Problem in graphs (STP) consists in finding a minimum-weight subgraph of G that spans all nodes in Q.In this paper, we consider the Min-max Regret Steiner Tree Problem with Interval Costs (MMR-STP), a robust variant of STP.In this variant, the weight of the edges are not known in advance, but are assumed to vary in the interval [l ij , u ij ].We develop an ILP formulation, an exact algorithm, and three heuristics for this problem.Computational experiments, performed on generalizations of the classical STP instances, evaluate the efficiency and the limits of the proposed methods.

title: A new algorithm for the Maximum-weight Planar Subgraph Problem

abstract: Algorithms for the problem of identifying a maximum edge-weight planar subgraph of a given edge-weighted graph G are relevant in a wide variety of application areas.We propose a new local search improvement heuristic algorithm for this N P-hard problem that is based on a polynomial-time transformation to the well-known connected spanning subgraph problem in the dual graph of G.When implemented on synthetically generated numerical instances and those from the literature, the algorithm usually performed at least as well as earlier, well-established heuristic methods for the problem.

abstract: The analysis of subjective factors that influence on group decision making can be performed, for instance, evaluating the negotiation style of the participants involved.Negotiation style can be measured through TKI ® scale, a self-report questionnaire that assesses individual's behavior in conflict situations and describes it along two dimensions: (i) assertiveness and (ii) cooperativeness.In parallel, refined models for a sequential group decision making should include psychological aspects of altruism and reciprocity.As an example, [Gimon and Leoneti 2020] proposed to model psychological components as a combination of two parameters, which are: (i) altruism and (ii) reciprocity, for refining a utility function that models multicriteria group decision making as games.In this work, we aimed to verify if TKI ® can be efficiently used for parameters' definition of the refined utility function and to analyze if the refined utility function's predictability, within a heterogeneous sequential group decision-making process, can be enhanced by the knowledge of the negotiation style of each participant.This result is important for guiding group decision making process in organizations, since it is a common place in organizations nowadays.

abstract: The set of reservoir inflows at the hydro power plants of Interconnected Power System (SIN) is one of the main variable that impacts the Short-term Marginal Cost (CMO) of Brazilian Power System, which, in turn, affects the Clearance Price (PLD).Due to the amount of uncertainties, the PLD forecast problem is the key issue for the middle office of a energy trader.This paper deals with PLD forecasting and presents three different techniques of transforming precipitation into inflows.The application of the statistical criteria indicates that the use of these technologies represents, in general, a satisfactory performance in the PLD forecasts, especially when the GEFS climate model integrated with the hydrological model is used.

abstract: The article aims to present a multicriteria decision analysis method named by the acronym ADRIANA (Análise Decisória Relativa Interativa de Aquisição e Não-Aquisição).The method is inspired by Richard Thaler's Behavioral Accounting work in which it divides total utility into the sum of acquisition and transaction utilities.In addition to an overview of its business management applications as a decision-making tool, the paper provides an example of its functionality and concludes with the graphical representation of Thaler value using the Tversky and Kahneman curve, Prospect Theory.The method is limited to numerical data and presents order reversal problems when entering or exiting alternatives and/or criteria.

abstract: The most common cause of interruptions in the supply of electricity to distribution networks comes from a combination of vegetation interference with adverse weather conditions.In this work, the vegetation maintenance problem is formulated as a combinatorial multiobjective optimization problem that determines the optimal tree trimming schedules in the distribution feeder sections.The optimization model considers two conflicting objective functions: one is the cost of the customer represented by the customer interruption cost; and the other is the utility costs through the vegetation maintenance cost.A methodology is presented to obtain the vegetation failure rate in the feeder sections, using a reliability index and a vegetation growth model.The solution technique of the proposed multiobjective optimization model is the elitist nondominated sorting genetic algorithm II.
